messages.text: because we have the `/delay` and `/drip` endpoints, I can see a possible situation where `nginx` runs out of connections (it defaults to 512 connections, but since it needs connections to the upstream as well, it’s actually just an effective 256 simultaneous streams).

messages.text: I’ve just deployed a significant update to the PkgServers

elements.text: I’ve just deployed a significant update to the PkgServers

messages.text: please keep an eye out for strange failures, but if all goes well, this should significantly increase performance and decrease failures, as we’re offloading the majority of happy-path requests to nginx.

elements.text: please keep an eye out for strange failures, but if all goes well, this should significantly increase performance and decrease failures, as we’re offloading the majority of happy-path requests to nginx.

messages.text: Over the past few weeks I’ve also done a lot of work on the StorageServers, so (fingers crossed) we should be in a good place, reliability-wise.  Time will tell of course, and the next project is to increase visibility into the failures of these by having a logging dashboard where we can see what proportion of requests to the PkgServers are failing (previously it was quite high at ~3%)

elements.text: Over the past few weeks I’ve also done a lot of work on the StorageServers, so (fingers crossed) we should be in a good place, reliability-wise. attachments.fallback:
[January 2nd, 2021 2:21 PM] max278: Julia CI tests for buildbot/package_win32 and buildbot/package_win64 are failing with error: `
```C:/buildbot/worker/package_win32/build/usr/tools/llvm-size.exe: error while loading shared libraries: LLVM.dll: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory```
This is right after `LLVM.v11.0.0+6.i686-w64-mingw32-cxx11.tar.gz` gets installed. So perhaps a bug in that JLL? <@U67BJLYCS>?
attachments.text:
Julia CI tests for buildbot/package_win32 and buildbot/package_win64 are failing with error: `
```C:/buildbot/worker/package_win32/build/usr/tools/llvm-size.exe: error while loading shared libraries: LLVM.dll: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory```
This is right after `LLVM.v11.0.0+6.i686-w64-mingw32-cxx11.tar.gz` gets installed. So perhaps a bug in that JLL? <@U67BJLYCS>?

messages.text: If someone wants a job working on this kind of stuff, contact me <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/devops-and-mlops-with-the-mit-julia-lab/52795>

attachments.title: Devops and MLops with the MIT Julia Lab
attachments.text: We’re looking for a new devops and MLops engineer to work with the Julia Lab. You’d be in charge of keeping all of our systems running and creating new schemes to accelerate Julia development. Julia’s Base CI, the FluxML, SciML and GPU resources are managed by this position. Automated benchmarking tools, automating the installation of Julia in R and Python packages, helping improve Julia’s setup for compute clusters, building tools to make it easy to manage ML training in Git repositories, etc. ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Devops and MLops with the MIT Julia Lab

elements.text: If someone wants a job working on this kind of stuff, contact me

messages.text: cannot quite follow the claim that the CI is quite stable now... I am looking at my three open PRs, and they all have 2-3 spuriously failed jobs -- and that is after I rebased them to force a re-run, to cure the previous failures (those were indeed fixed, but now there are new ones)
yeah I jinxed it

elements.text: yeah I jinxed it

messages.text: well, several of them look like download / network failures, so transient. But honestly it feels to me as if there was always something failing... Let me emphasis that I understand how difficult it can be to get these things stable, and how many hours or days one can waste on it -- been there, done there, for other (smaller) projects. But I feel it really takes away a lot from a CI if one cannot rely on the "green = good,  red = can ignore until submitter fixes it". Currently it seems to me as if most PRs are red even if they are perfectly fine. Again: that's my subjective impression from following PRs for a couple months now. Maybe I am wrong

elements.text: well, several of them look like download / network failures, so transient. But honestly it feels to me as if there was always something failing... But I feel it really takes away a lot from a CI if one cannot rely on the "green = good,  red = can ignore until submitter fixes it".
